1:
Surely there is a mine for silver,\q a place where they refine gold.
\q
2:
Iron is taken out of the earth;\q copper is smelted out of the stone.


\q
3:
A man sets an end to darkness\q and searches out, to the farthest limit,
\q the stones in obscurity and thick darkness.
\q
4:
He breaks open a shaft away from where people live,\q places that are forgotten by anyone's foot.
\q He hangs far away from people; he swings to and fro.


\q
5:
As for the earth, out of which comes bread,\q it is turned up below as if by fire.
\q
6:
Its stones are the place where sapphires are found,\q and its dust contains gold.


\q
7:
No bird of prey knows the path to it,\q nor has the falcon's eye seen it.
\q
8:
The proud animals have not walked such a path,\q nor has the fierce lion passed there.


\q
9:
A man lays his hand on the flinty rock;\q he overturns mountains by their roots.
\q
10:
He cuts out channels among the rocks;\q his eye sees every valuable thing there.
\q
11:
He ties up the streams so they do not run;\q what is hidden there he brings out to the light.
\m


\q
12:
Where will wisdom be found?\q Where is the place of understanding?
\q
13:
Man does not know its price;\q neither is it found in the land of the living.
\q
14:
The deep waters under the earth say, 'It is not in me';\q the sea says, 'It is not with me.'


\q
15:
It cannot be gotten for gold;\q neither can silver be weighed as its price.
\q
16:
It cannot be valued with the gold of Ophir,\q with precious onyx or sapphire.
\q
17:
Gold and crystal cannot equal it in worth;\q neither can it be exchanged for jewels of fine gold.


\q
18:
No mention is worth making of coral or jasper;\q indeed, the price of wisdom is more than rubies.
\q
19:
The topaz of Cush does not equal it;\q neither can it be valued in terms of pure gold.


\q
20:
From where, then, comes wisdom?\q Where is the place of understanding?
\q
21:
Wisdom is hidden from the eyes of all living things\q and is kept hidden from the birds of the heavens.
\q
22:
Destruction and Death say,\q 'We have heard just a rumor about it with our ears.'
\m


\q
23:
God understands the way to it;\q he knows its place.
\q
24:
For he looks to the very ends of the earth\q and sees under all the heavens.
\q
25:
He made the force of the wind\q and parceled out the waters by measure.


\q
26:
He made a decree for the rain\q and a path for the thunder.
\q
27:
Then he saw wisdom and announced it;\q he established it, indeed, and he examined it.
\q
28:
To people he said,\q 'See, the fear of the Lordâ€”that is wisdom;
\q to depart from evil is understanding.'"
